questions.text:
A respiratory therapist presents to the OPD with abdominal pain. He also complains of low-grade fever, night sweats, and loss of weight. You investigate him for intestinal tuberculosis. Which of the following radiological signs are expected to be seen in him?
  1. String sign
  2. Creeping fat sign
  3. Sterlein sign
  4. Fleishner sign
  5. Apple core sign
questions.solution:
Creeping fat sign and apple core sign are not the radiological findings seen in intestinal tuberculosis.

The creeping fat sign refers to the widely separated bowel loops due to fibrofatty proliferation seen in Crohn's disease.

The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core. This appearance is classically seen in a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kocher’s thyroid dissector which is used during a thyroidectomy to dissect the upper pole of the thyroid.

The instrument is blunt and therefore damage to the superior thyroid artery or external laryngeal nerve is unlikely.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Where is Rasmussen’s aneurysm seen?
questions.solution:
The aneurysm of the pulmonary artery within the tuberculous cavity is called Rasmussen’s aneurysm.

Rasmussen's aneurysm is an inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation. This occurs during the healing of the tuberculous cavity. There is a progressive weakening of the arterial wall, in which both the tunica adventitia and media are replaced by granulation tissue. This is gradually replaced by fibrin resulting in thinning of the arterial wall leading to pseudoaneurysm formation.

Rupture of Rasmussen's aneurysm can cause massive hemoptysis. CT angiography plays an important role in locating the aneurysm.

Most cases of massive hemoptysis arise from the bronchial arterial tree because of high pressure within bronchial arteries. Even when a pulmonary aneurysm is present, the actual bleeding may be from the bronchial artery, rather than from the pulmonary artery itself.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is the treatment of choice for tumors <4 cm.

Indications for partial nephrectomy:

  • Tumors < 4cm
  • Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm
  • Bilateral tumors
  • Tumor in solitary kidneys
  • Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction.

Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. 

Treatment of renal cell carcinoma: 

RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Staging  Description  Management 
Stage 1  Tumor <7 cm, confined to the kidney Partial nephrectomy 
Stage 2  Tumor >7 cm, confined to the kidney Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 3  Tumor extends into the major veins or adrenal gland with intact Gerota’s fascia or regional lymph nodes involved.  Radical nephrectomy 
Stage 4  Tumor invades beyond Gerota fascia (including contiguous extension into the ipsilateral adrenal gland) 
  • Debulking surgery
  • mTOR inhibitors such as everolimus, sirolimus
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors: sunitinib, sorafenib

Radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is no longer removed except in cases of obvious tumor involvement. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumors and enlarged lymph nodes.

Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/metastatic tumors. 

Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

  • Retinal angiomas (benign)
  • CNS hemangioblastomas (benign)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors

  • Endolymphatic sac tumors
Hereditary papillary RCC C-met proto-oncogene (7q31)
  • Multiple & bilateral type1 papillary RCC
Tuberous sclerosis  TSC1 (9q34) TSC2 (16p13)

  • Multiple renal angiomyolipomas
  • Polycystic kidney disease

  • Cardiac Rhabdomyoma

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Carney's triad?
questions.solution:
Carney's triad does not include pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

Carney’s triad consists of:

  1. Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
  2. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  3. Pulmonary chondroma

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: A man was referred for the evaluation of an unsteady gait with weakness of his legs for the past 1 month. He gave a history of similar problems in his brother. Imaging revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas and bilateral renal masses suggestive of RCC.  Which histological type of this renal malignancy is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma which along with the family history points to a diagnosis of von Hippel Lindau’s disease (VHL). Clear cell RCC is the most common type associated with VHL disease. 

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is caused by a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A second hit can increase the predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina, and clear cell renal carcinoma(in 40-60%).

The given slide shows clear cell RCC.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the following statements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP.

The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.

It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome.

Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. 

Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas.

The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below.  Which of the following statements is false about his condition?

choices.text: Cyst wall is lined by squamous epithelium.
Splenic artery is the most common artery involved.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis.

Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery.

 Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include:

  • Abscess
  • Systemic sepsis
  • GI bleeding
  • Fistula formation
  • Peritonitis
  • Obstructive jaundice
  • Bowel obstruction
  • Hemorrhage into the cyst
  • Hemoperitoneum

Pancreatic pseudo­cysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student sustained a superficial injury to his neck during a bar fight. What is the probable cause of sudden death in this patient?

choices.text: Air embolism through external jugular vein

questions.solution:
Air embolism through the external jugular vein is a cause of sudden death in patients with superficial neck injury.

All other structures are deeper structures, hence are not involved much in superficial injuries of the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following are false regarding first-degree burns?

choices.text: Protective functions of the skin are intact
No residual scar after injury heals

questions.solution:
First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, are painful, but do not blister, protective functions of the skin are intact and heals without a scar.

Second-degree burns have dermal involvement and are extremely painful and blister.

Third-degree burns are leathery, painless, and non-blanching.

Related Pearl: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound during a master health check-up. The size of the pseudocyst is 5 cm and is located in the tail of the pancreas. Past history is notable for two episodes of acute pancreatitis. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Observation is the preferred treatment in this case since the size of the pseudocyst is <6 cm and is arising from the tail of the pancreas.

Indications for conservative management in pancreatic pseudocyst:

  • Asymptomatic patients
  • Pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm (according to Bailey)
  • Located on the tail
  • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

questions.text: A patient with a pancreatic neoplasm undergoes cyst fluid aspiration. The aspirated fluid stains positive for mucin and shows elevated levels of amylase and CEA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positive mucin staining, elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and elevated amylase levels are seen in cases of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN).

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology

Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid–Schiff stain

Sheets and clusters of columnar, mucin-containing cells

Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells
Mucin stain Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

questions.text:
You assist in performing a Whipple procedure in a patient with carcinoma of the pancreas. All of the following structures will be resected in this surgery, except:
  1. Gallbladder
  2. Common bile duct
  3. Spleen
  4. Proximal jejunum
  5. Tail of the pancreas
questions.solution:
Whipple procedure does not involve the removal of the spleen and tail of the pancreas.

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus preserving pancreatoduodectomy

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction. 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

Melena is the passage of black, tarry stools. It is seen in upper GI bleeding. Hematochezia is the passage of fresh blood with stools. It is seen in lower GI bleeding.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old diabetic patient with a frail built comes to the OPD. His wife is concerned about his recent weight loss and lack of appetite. Which parameters will you consider while assessing his malnutrition using MUST?
  1. BMI
  2. Age
  3. Recent weight loss
  4. Current nutritional intake
  5. Acute illness
questions.solution:
Age is not a criterion used in MUST.

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) is a five-step screening tool to identify malnourished adults or adults at risk of malnutrition.

Related Pearl: Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST)

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool, ‘MUST’ is a five-step screening tool to identify adults, who are malnourished, at risk of malnutrition (undernutrition), or obese. It also includes management guidelines which can be used to develop a care plan.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a resected specimen of a gallbladder with a polyp on the inner surface. 

Specimen of gallbladder carcinoma would include an en-bloc dissection of the gall bladder, surrounding liver tissue and regional lymph nodes (option D). In specimens of cholesterolosis, also known as strawberry gallbladder, the gall bladder would appear yellow and coarsely granular due to the presence lipid nodules (options A and B).

Gall bladder polyps are usually incidental findings during abdominal imaging. Most of them are benign and comprise cholesterol polyps, adenomyomas or inflammatory polyps. Adenomatous polyps are the most common neoplastic polyps. The majority of patients with polyps are stable and smaller polyps are kept under observation. Cholecystectomy is done for symptomatic patients (biliary colic, pancreatitis), patients >50 years, sessile polyps with thickening >4 mm and polyps >10 mm.

The risk factors for malignancy in an adenomatous polyp include age >50 years, size >10 mm, sessile polyp, documented increase in size, and coexistence with gallstones.

Other options: 

Option D: The gallbladder in a patient with carcinoma is removed via an en-bloc dissection with surrounding liver tissue along with regional lymph nodes. The given image below shows a cut surface of the resected gallbladder with a tumor at the neck along with liver bed involvement (marked by the red arrow). 

Options A and B: Cholesterolosis (strawberry gallbladder) is characterized by the accumulation of lipids (triglycerides, cholesterol precursors and cholesterol esters) in the lamina propria of the gallbladder wall. The nodules are less than 1 mm in diameter and there is mucous villous hyperplasia, which gives it a coarse, yellow and granular appearance, giving it a strawberry-like appearance. The given images below show cholesterolosis.

Related Pearl: Indication for Cholecystectomy in Gallbladder Polyp

  • All symptomatic patients
  • All asymptomatic patients >50 years
  • Polyp of size >10 mm
  • Evidence of polyp growth on serial ultrasonography

questions.text: Children with MEN2B mutation should undergo thyroidectomy by age of:
questions.solution: Children with mutations at codon 634 are advised to undergo thyroidectomy at <5 years of age, and those with MEN2B-related mutations should undergo the procedure before age 1. Central neck dissection can be avoided in children who are RET-positive and calcitonin negative with a normal ultrasound examination. When the calcitonin is increased or the ultrasound suggests a thyroid cancer, a prophylactic central neck dissection is indicated.

questions.text: What is the earliest sign of post-operative volume overload in a patient?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of volume overload in a patient is weight gain.

The administration of isotonic fluids in excess of actual needs commonly results in excess volume expansion. This may be due to the overestimation of third-space losses or due to ongoing GI losses that are difficult to measure accurately.

The average postoperative patient who is not receiving nutritional support should lose approximately 0.11 to 0.23 kg/day from catabolism.

Other signs of volume overload include:

Cardiac:

  • Increased cardiac output         
  • Increased central venous pressure       
  • Distended neck veins          
  • Murmur

GI: Bowel edema

Pulmonary: Pulmonary edema

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved by loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with X-ray findings showing a retrocardiac gas bubble are consistent with the diagnosis of a hiatus hernia. A CT scan with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis. It highlights the gastric anatomy but also helps to identify other structures involved in the hiatal hernia.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1- sliding hernia

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication.

Type 2- rolling hiatus hernia:

Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia.

Clinical features:

  • Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching.
  • Dysphagia.
  • Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleed lead to anemia.

Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus.

Type 3- mixed hiatus hernia:

A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia:

Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon.

Note: This is a controversial question as some books give barium swallow as the investigation of choice for hiatal hernia. But Bailey's 28th edition clearly mentions that a CT scan with oral contrast is the answer.

The image below shows a retrocardiac gas bubble on an X-ray that is consistent with hiatus hernia.

questions.text: For what purpose would you use the instrument shown in the image?

choices.text: To hold tough tissue like skin and fascia

questions.solution:
The above image is of Lister’s sinus forceps which are used for blunt dissection.

It is used during Hilton's method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.

It is also used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents to the OPD with complaints of recent onset pain in her feet. Blood investigation showed elevated PTH levels and normal serum calcium values. All of the following mechanisms contribute to elevated PTH in this patient except _____

choices.text: Stimulation of parathyroid cells by hyperphosphatemia
Increased secretion of FGF-23 by osteocytes
Reduced expression of Vitamin D receptors and CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) in bones
Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described here showing elevated PTH and normal calcium levels is that of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure. Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway is the proposed mechanism of secondary hyperparathyroidism in the setting of lithium consumption and not renal hyperparathyroidism.

Causes for increased PTH in secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure:

  • Abnormal renal tubular reabsorption → hyperphosphatemia → stimulation of parathyroid cells → elevated PTH
  • Increased FGF-23 secretion from osteocytes →  decreased 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D → decreased intestinal absorption of calcium → elevated PTH
  • Normally, ECF calcium controls PTH secretion by interacting with CaSR. Stimulation of CaSR by high calcium suppresses PTH secretion. In chronic renal disease, there is reduced expression of Vitamin D and CaSR by bones → increased skeletal resistance to PTH → elevated PTH.

Related Pearl: Parathyroid Diseases

questions.text: Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation is indicated in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: As standby procedure till a suitable donor is found
Acute fulminant liver failure that is irreversible

questions.solution:
Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation (A-OLTX) is indicated in non-cirrhotic metabolic liver disease.

Auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation is a technique where part of the diseased native liver is removed and replaced with a part of the healthy donor liver. This is done so the retained native liver can regenerate. 

In selective cases of acute liver failure, auxiliary partial orthotopic liver transplantation could provide a chance for native liver regeneration and immunosuppression-free life.

Auxillary orthotopic liver transplant is indicated for the following:

  • Patients aged <40 years
  • Reversible fulminant hepatic failure (auxiliary liver transplantation cannot be done in cases of irreversible liver failure) 
  • Non-cirrhotic metabolic liver disease
  • No hemodynamic instability
  • Hyperacute (not in other cases) Liver failure with Acetaminophen overdose.
Total orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX)  Auxiliary orthotopic liver transplantation (A-OLTX) 

 The entire liver is transplanted 

 Only a portion of the liver is transplanted

Indications:

  • Fulminant hepatic failure (FHF)
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis

Indications:

  • Crigler–Najjar syndrome type I
  • Homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Galactosemia 
  • Hereditary tyrosinemia 
  • Neimann-Pick's disease
Life-long immunosuppression is required. Immunosuppression is required until the native liver regenerates

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: With regard to genetic alterations in tumorigenesis of thyroid malignancies, match the following correctly:
questions.solution:
A. (3) RET

  • Located on Chromosome 10

  • RET mutations can cause developmental abnormalities in the embryonic nervous and excretory systems like Hirschsprung’s disease. 

  • RET rearrangements are associated with increased radiation exposure. 

B. (1) Mutations of p53 are rare in PTCs but common in undifferentiated thyroid cancers and thyroid cancer cell lines.

C. (2) Papillary thyroid carcinomas develop as a result of activation of Ras, Raf, and MEK are signalling molecules in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway.  

D. (4) Follicular carcinomas are associated with PAX8/ PPAR gamma.

questions.text: Most important predictor of survival in patients with adrenal cancer:
questions.solution:
The most important predictor of survival in patients with adrenal cancer is the adequacy of resection.

Prognosis: poor prognosis

Patients who undergo:

  • complete resection have 5-year actuarial survival rates ranging from 32% to 48%
  • incomplete excision have median  survival of  <1 year

Incision:

  • Therefore, adrenocortical carcinomas are treated by excision of the tumor en bloc with any contiguously involved lymph nodes or organs such as the diaphragm, kidney, pancreas, liver, or IVC.
  • This is best accomplished by open adrenalectomy via a generous subcostal incision or a thoracoabdominal incision (on the right side).

The incisions should :

  • permit wide exposure
  • minimize chances of capsule rupture and tumor spillage
  • allow vascular control of the aorta, IVC, and renal vessels, as needed.

Mitotane  has adrenolytic activity and has been used in the adjuvant setting and for the treatment of unresectable or metastatic disease.

Laparoscopic adrenalectomy has high recurrence and hence not recommended.

After surgery restaging is required every 3 months as high recurrence risk.

questions.text: Which part of the GIT is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult?
questions.solution:
Tonometry studies have shown that of all the parts of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), the stomach is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult and is also the slowest to recover.

This may explain the high incidence of stress ulceration in the stomach.

The Griffiths point (or Griffiths critical point) refers to the site of watershed anastomosis between the ascending left colic artery and the marginal artery of Drummond occurring in the region of the splenic flexure. Most anatomy texts describe its location as two-thirds along the transverse colon.

The Sudeck point (or Sudeck critical point) refers to a specific location in the arterial supply of the rectosigmoid junction, namely the origin of the last sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).

questions.text: All are true about intestinal transplantation except ______.

choices.text: Most of the grafts are multi-visceral grafts.
It is not widely used due to vigorous rejection reactions.
The most dangerous complication is sepsis.
The most common indication is the ischemia

questions.solution:
Multivisceral grafts are rarely used in intestinal transplantation. The most common intestinal graft is small bowel graft, with or without the colon or a combined liver and small bowel graft.

All the other statements are correct.

Small bowel transplantation is the final treatment option after the outcome of reconstruction and lengthening procedures are unsatisfactory.

The small bowel transplant is highly immunogenic since it contains a large amount of gut-associated lymphoid tissue, donor dendritic cells, and macrophages. Acute rejection has been reported in 56–75% of patients, with small bowel transplant limiting the overall survival to only one-third of recipients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck. He also complained of persistent cough and regurgitation of food remnants shortly after consumption. He underwent a barium swallow which is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Occurs in the midline posteriorly and as sac enlarges lies on the left side
Dohlman’s procedure is indicated when size > 2-5 cm
Herniates through the thyropharyngeus and cricothyroid muscle

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a Zenker’s diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch. It is caused due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the space between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus. This space is known as Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor in the posterior pharyngeal wall.

It is a pulsion diverticulum, formed due to increased intraluminal pressure forcing mucosa and submucosa to herniate.

A small Zenker’s diverticulum < 2cm is managed by diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy. 

Large diverticulum > 2-5cm is treated by endoscopic diverticulopexy (Dohlman’s procedure) or by a diverticulectomy with cricopharyngeal myotomy. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A patient with toxic adenoma is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this?

choices.text: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.solution:
The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery.

Toxic adenoma is a benign functioning thyroid tumour, which usually presents as a toxic solitary nodule. It is an autonomously functioning tumour that does not respond to TSH. Treatment involves antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine. This is followed by hemithyroidectomy as the surrounding normal thyroid tissue regains normal function.

Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are two methods of preparation that can be used:

  1. Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced. Beta-blockers, if used preoperatively, must be given on the morning of surgery and continued for a week post-op.
  2. Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily may be given to achieve beta-blockade. It is important to continue treatment up to 7 days postoperatively.

Iodine may be given with carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. It produces transient remission and reduces thyroid vascularity.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: A  patient presented with acute worsening of edema of the left hand, which was present for the past 5 years. Her surgical history was relevant for a radical mastectomy with radiation therapy for left-sided breast carcinoma. On examination, the limb appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Stewart–Treves syndrome.

The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or in association with post-mastectomy lymphedema. It presents with acute worsening of edema with subcutaneous nodules which are hemorrhagic or ulcerative.

Treatment is preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation of arm). The prognosis is poor.

Option A: Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the muscle tissue, mostly in children and adolescents.

Option D: Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues.

questions.text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.solution:
The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. 

Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week.

Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac. 

The treatment is as follows:

  • Preservation of the intact sac with a sterile, moistened, saline gauze or transparent bowel bag.
  • IV fluids should be started, along with gastric tube decompression and IV antibiotics.
  • Topical application of povidone-iodine ointment, merbromin (mercurochrome), or silver nitrate allows the sac to thicken and epithelialize gradually.
  • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. 

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Schistosomiasis can lead to tropical splenomegaly
Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia
Howell-Jolly bodies are seen in asplenia

questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis occurs following splenectomy.

This occurs particularly in patients with myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia, polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis). It may result in thrombosis of the mesenteric, portal, and renal veins which can be life-threatening as it can lead to haemorrhage and thromboembolism.

Option A: Tropical splenomegaly is massive splenic enlargement, which frequently occurs in the tropics due to malaria, kala-azar, and schistosomiasis.

Option C: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.

Option D: Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as dense blue colored circular inclusions as shown in the image below. They are usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia).

questions.text: Which of the following is not an important cause of hypokalemia?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia may occur as a result of metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

The following are various causes of hypokalemia:

  • Inadequate intake
    • Diet, potassium-free intravenous fluids, potassium deficient TPN
  • Excessive potassium excretion
    • Hyperaldosteronism
    • Medications 
  • Potassium losses
    • Direct loss of potassium from GI fluid (diarrhea)
    • Renal loss of potassium (to conserve sodium in response to gastric losses) 
  • Metabolic
    • Intracellular potassium shifts from metabolic alkalosis or insulin therapy

Vomiting leads to hypokalemia via complex pathogenesis. The gastric fluid itself contains little potassium, approximately 10 mEq/L. However, vomiting produces volume depletion and metabolic alkalosis.

Volume depletion leads to secondary hyperaldosteronism leads to enhanced cortical collecting tubule secretion of potassium in response to enhanced sodium reabsorption. Metabolic alkalosis further increases potassium secretion by the collecting tubule due to the decreased availability of hydrogen ions.

questions.text: In patients with head trauma, which of the following is least likely to cause secondary brain injuries?
questions.solution:
Hypercapnea (and not hypocapnea) is a cause of secondary brain injury. 

It is essential to avoid hypercapnia in patients with head injury since it will raise intracranial pressure (ICP). While hyperventilation is an effective way of managing acute intracranial hypertension, it should be remembered that it can produce a dangerous decrease in cerebral blood flow, especially if cerebral perfusion pressure is low. 

Primary brain injury (focal and diffuse) results from mechanical injury at the time of the trauma. Secondary brain injury is caused by the physiologic responses to the initial injury. This is thought to involve a cascade of events, with edema and hematomas leading to increased intracranial pressure, which leads to compression and deformation of surrounding brain tissue and further damage. 

 Causes of secondary brain injury:

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypotension
  • Raised ICP >20 mmHg
  • Low cerebral perfusion pressure
  • Hypercapnea
  • Hyperthermia
  • Seizures
  • Metabolic disturbance (hyperglycemia)

questions.text:
While starting fluid resuscitation on a patient with burns, it is important to keep in mind that all of the following parameters will be decreased, except:
  1. Hemoglobin 
  2. Intravascular volume 
  3. Capillary permeability 
  4. Cardiac output
  5. Afterload
questions.solution:
Capillary permeability and afterload is increased after severe burns.

Significant burns is associated with massive release of inflammatory mediators, both in the wound and in other tissues. These mediators produce vasoconstriction and vasodilation, increased capillary permeability, and edema locally and in distant organs.

Cellular and humoral immunity are decreased in burns (increased risk of infection).

Changes in various systems in burns:

CVS

  • Massive edema
  • Increased afterload
  • Decreased venous return
  • Decreased cardiac output

Renal

  • Low volume concentrated urine
  • Decreased urinary sodium
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Renal ischemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Acute renal failure

GI

  • Reflex Ileus
  • GI Ulcers (Curling’s Ulcer)

Endocrine and Metabolism

  • Increased glucagon, cortisol
  • Protein catabolism
  • Ureagenesis
  • Lipolysis
  • Increased gluconeogenesis
  • Lactic acidosis

Hematological

  • Anaemia
  • Initial thrombocytopenia then thrombocytosis
  • Decreased capacity of neutrophil phagocytosis
  • Overall lymphopenia
  • Relative increase in T-Suppressor Cells

questions.text: Amebic liver abscess ruptures most commonly into the ______.
questions.solution:
Amebic liver abscess ruptures most commonly into the pleural cavity.

Free rupture into the peritoneal cavity is uncommon and occurs in moribund patients or those with poor nutrition. Thoracic amebiasis (empyema, bronchohepatic fistulas, and pleuropulmonary abscess) is the most common complication, followed by pericardial amebiasis.

Rupture m.c site: subdiaphragmatic>pleural>peritoneal.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at the blood bank and receive several units of packed RBCs, platelets, fresh frozen plasma, and cryoprecipitate following a blood donation camp. Which among the following components would you want to use at the earliest?
questions.solution:
Platelets have a shelf life of only 5 days and hence they have to be used at the earliest.

They are usually stored on a special agitator at 20–24 °C. They are given to the patients with thrombocytopenia or with platelet dysfunction who are bleeding or undergoing surgery.

Packed cells (PRBCs) are stored in a SAG-M solution (saline–adenine–glucose–mannitol) and has a shelf life of 42 days at 2–6 °C. (Older storage regimens included storage in CPD – citrate–phosphate–dextrose solutions which have a shelf life of 2–3 weeks.)

Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is stored at −40 to −50°C, while cryoprecipitate is stored at -30°C, and both have a shelf life of one years.

Related Pearl: Blood components

Whole blood 450 ml RBCs, platelets, plasma Hb and plasma volume    
Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 300-350 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL

Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -30 °C 1 year

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text: Regarding treatment  of hyperthyroidism false is:

choices.text: Recurrent thyrotoxicosis usually is managed by radioiodine treatment
RAI therapy is most often used in older patients with small or moderate-sized goiters
Surgery is usually  indicated in smokers with moderate to severe Graves’ ophthalmopathy
Methimazole is preferred in the first trimester of pregnancy

questions.solution:
• Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis. However,
    propylthiouracil can be associated with liver failure.
  • Propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester and then maternal therapy should be converted to methimazole (or carbimazole) at a ratio of 15–20 mg of propylthiouracil to 1 mg of methimazole.
  • Breast-feeding is safe with low doses of antithyroid drugs.

Adverse effects:

Antithyroid drugs - main side effects are agranulocytosis and hepatotoxicity.

RAI - lead to progression of Graves’ ophthalmopathy 

Treatment of hyperthyroidism:

1. Antithyroid drugs:

Drugs used- Propylthiouracil and methimazole

Indications-Preparation  for Radioactive ablation / surgery

Curative in:

  • Small nontoxic goiter <40 gms
  • Mildly elevated thyroid hormone levels
  • Rapid decrease in gland size following medications

Outcome – symptom improvement in 2 weeks

Euthyroid in 6 weeks

Disadvantage:  High relapse rate

2. Radioactive Iodine Ablation therapy

Indication:

  • Older patients with small / moderate sized goiters
  • Relapse cases
  • Contraindications for drugs or surgery

Contraindication :

  • Pregnancy , lactation (Absolute)
  • Young patients
  • Ophthalmopathy
  • Thyroid nodules

Disadv:

  • Progression of grave’s ophthalmopathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Increased risk of thyroid cancer

Outcome:Euthyroid in 2 months

3. Surgery

Indications:

  • When RAI therapy is contraindicated
  • When Rapid control of hyperthyroidism is desired
  • Poor response to anti thyroid drugs
  • Smoker’s with moderate to severe ophthalmopathy

Lugol’s iodine- Reduces vascularity and inhibits hormone release.

questions.text: The forearm of a patient admitted to the psychiatric ward is shown in the image. Which of the following is true about the healed injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic scars which have developed on possible sites of self-inflicted cuts. Type 3 collagen fibers are arranged parallelly in hypertrophic scars. This is in contrast to a keloid where the collagen fibers are more and randomly arranged. 

Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time. They have no racial or genetic predilection. 

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial Maybe familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on extensor surface) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text:
In patients with BCC, Mohs microscopic surgery will be indicated for which of the following features of the tumor?
  1. Recurrent tumor
  2. Tumor 1 cm in diameter
  3. Well differentiated tumor
  4. Tumor with perineural invasion
  5. Tumor involving the lip
questions.solution:
Moh’s microscopic surgery is indicated in patients with the following features of BCC:

  1. Primary lesions of the ear or lip
  2. Recurrent lesions
  3. With perineural invasion
  4. Poorly differentiated lesions
  5. Tumors more than 2 cm in size 

Moh’s microscopic surgery involves initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. These tissue samples are examined immediately under a frozen section for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally obtained.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident says that his bike handle hit the right side of his chest. On palpation, he had tenderness in the right upper chest. Chest radiograph shows a fracture in the right third rib. Which of the following should you not do while managing him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a rib fracture. Strapping is not done for rib fractures because it prevents the patient from taking deep breaths. This can lead to lung collapse.

The vital step in the management of rib fractures is to reduce pain and prevent the development of pneumonia. Rib fracture causes intense pain during breathing and increases the risk of pulmonary infections as the patient is not able to cough forcefully. 

In mild to moderate cases, pain can be managed by intravenous opioids. In severe cases, patients may require epidural analgesia.

In addition to adequate analgesia, chest physiotherapy like deep breathing, frequent coughing, incentive spirometry should be encouraged in these patients. This prevents the development of pneumonia and lung collapse. When chest wall injuries result in respiratory failure, mechanical ventilation should be provided.

questions.text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the  umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line

Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It is also called McBurney incision.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.text: During a clinical trial, it was found that some individuals who showed radioactive uptake on Sestamibi scan, showed no other evidence of hyperparathyroidism. They were instead found to be suffering from a Hurthle cell nodule of the thyroid gland. Which of the following radioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
questions.solution:
A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc-Pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules such as Hurthle cell nodule.

The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the parathyroid glands. Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation that accumulates in mitochondria. Due to this, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondria in each tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content and they retain tracers and have a slower washout compared to the normal glands.

In patients with nodular goiter or functional tumors of the thyroid gland, increased uptake of sestamibi by the thyroid gland makes parathyroid visualization difficult. There are two primary techniques to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue:

  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging (with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or 99mTc pertechnetate) -  99mTc pertechnetate is taken up only by the thyroid. The 99mTc pertechnetate scintigram is then digitally subtracted from the sestamibi scan to allow parathyroid localization.
  • Single-isotope dual-phase imaging (with sesta­mibi alone with early and delayed imaging) - since the rate of washout from the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland is slower when compared to the thyroid gland.

The image given below shows the dual-isotope subtraction imaging.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with thyroid swellings is least likely to require surgery?

choices.text: A 22 year old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category IV
A 66 year old man with a positive Pemberton’s sign
A 58 year old man with an FNAC report of Thy2
A 16 year old girl with recurrence of thyroid cyst

questions.solution:
FNAC report of Thy2 i.e. non-neoplastic is not an indication for surgery. 

Indications for surgical management of thyroid swellings include:

  • Neoplasia: FNAC positive Thy3–5 and clinical suspicion
    • Age
    • Male sex
    • Hard texture
    • Fixity
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Recurrent cyst
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Cosmesis
  • Patient’s wishes

questions.text: In a suspected case of bowel obstruction, the presence of which of the following helps you to distinguish the small intestine from the large intestine?
questions.solution:
The presence of valvule conniventes (plicae circulares) helps to distinguish the small intestine from the large intestine. They are prominent mucosal folds seen in the gross examination of the small intestine and are also visible radiographically. They are more prominent in the jejunum.

Radiological differences between small bowel and large bowel obstruction are:

Radiological features Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid faeces Absent Present

Investigation of choice: CECT abdomen (adults); USG abdomen (children)

questions.text: What is the most common type of pancreatic malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ductal adenocarcinoma is the most common type of pancreatic cancer.

Types of exocrine pancreatic cancer:

  • Ductal adenocarcinoma (85%)
  • Adenosquamous carcinoma
  • Acinar cell carcinoma

Endocrine cancer of the pancreas is rare. They account for only 5% of clinically detected pancreatic tumours.

questions.text: The most common malignant brain tumor in children is ________.
questions.solution:
Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumour in children.

They are usually midline. Most of them occur in the cerebellum and present with symptoms of increased ICP. 

Most common tumours in children:

  • Brain tumours are the most common solid tumours.
  • Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumour (usually not malignant).
  • Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour.
  • Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumours.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A middle-aged woman underwent a trucut biopsy for the suspicion of malignancy on a mammogram. Microscopy showed the presence of invasive breast carcinoma. IHC staining of the tumor is given below. Which of the following drugs will you add along with chemotherapeutic agents for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. Chemotherapy along with endocrine therapy, and trastuzumab is the adjuvant treatment of choice.

Positive immunohistochemistry staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given for patients with tumors that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given for patients with tumors that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy is given for hormone negative, HER2+, and ER+ tumors.

The table below shows the summary of the adjuvant treatment approach:

  Tumor hormone receptor status (ER,PR)
Tumor HER2/neu status Positive Negative  
Positive Endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab Chemotherapy + trastuzumab
Negative Endocrine therapy ± chemotherapy Chemotherapy

Note: Palbociclib is used along with hormone therapy in ER +ve, PR +ve, HER2/neu -ve tumors.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the anatomy of the anal canal below the pectinate line?

choices.text: Lymphatic drainage is to inguinal nodes
Innervation is by the inferior rectal nerves
Venous drainage is into the systemic circulation
Tumors are more likely to be adenocarcinoma

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma is more likely to be seen above the pectinate line. Tumors below the pectinate line are more likely to be squamous cell carcinoma. 

The pectinate line is at the junction of the upper two-thirds and the lower one-third of the anal canal. Developmentally, it represents the hindgut–proctodeum junction. The part of the anal canal above this line developed from the hindgut and the part below developed from the proctodeum.

questions.text:
Cholangiohepatitis is associated with which of the following parasites?
  1. Clonorchis sinensis
  2. Opisthorchis viverrini
  3. Schistosoma haematobium
  4. Ascaris lumbricoides
  5. Paragonimus westermani
questions.solution:
Cholangiohepatitis or recurrent pyogenic cholangitis is associated with biliary parasites such as:

  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Opisthorchis viverrini
  • Ascaris lumbricoides.

It is caused by bacterial contamination of the biliary tree. Some commonly implicated organisms are Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, Bacteroides species, or Enterococcus faecalis.

Cholangiohepatitis is a pre-malignant condition and can result in cholangiocarcinoma.

Schistosoma haematobium primarily causes genito-urinary schistosomiasis. 

Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) causes a pulmonary syndrome characterized by cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis.

questions.text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is a radio- sensitive tumor
The most common type is adenocarcinoma
It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
It arises from the renal cortex, usually from a pre- existing adenoma

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly man with intermittent flank pain and the CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. Renal cell carcinoma is a radio-resistant tumor.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises from the epithelium of the proximal convoluted tubule and is frequently detected coincidentally. It has a male preponderance.

There are six major subtypes which are clear-cell, papillary, chromophobe, MiT family translocation, collecting duct, and medullary type.

The classic triad of loin pain, loin mass, and haematuria is seen in <10% of patients with renal tumors. Rather, the majority of diagnoses result from incidental findings during procedures like CT imaging, performed for other reasons.

Major risk factors for RCC include age, sex, obesity, hypertension, and cigarette smoking. Other medical conditions associated with RCC include chronic kidney disease, hemodialysis, kidney transplantation, and acquired cystic disease of the kidney (ACDK).

Genetic factors also contribute to an increased risk of RCC, evidenced by individuals with a family history of renal cancer having an approximately twofold increased risk. The most common symptoms associated with paraneoplastic syndromes are hypercalcemia, fever, and erythrocytosis.

Surgeries done for RCC include:

  • Partial nephrectomy, the goal of which is to completely remove the primary tumor while preserving the largest possible amount of healthy renal parenchyma. It is used for renal tumors <7cm in size.
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.

There also exist targeted therapies for RCC which include tyrosine kinase inhibitors like sorafenib, sunitinib, and lenvatinib, anti-VEGF monoclonal antibodies like bevacizumab, and mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and temsirolimus. The average duration of disease control with these agents is 8–9 months. 

Other options: 

  • Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC.

  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of RCC, arising from the renal tubular cells.

  • RCC arises from the renal cortex, usually from a pre- existing adenoma.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the dermatologist's office with multiple small bumps on his forehead. Excisional biopsy findings are suggestive of multiple small sebaceous adenomas. Detailed family history reveals that his grandfather and brother have colon cancer while his aunt was diagnosed with rectal cancer. Which syndrome should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas and a family history of various cancers are seen in Muir–Torre syndrome.

Muir–Torre variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) may have:

  • Sebaceous adenomas
  • Keratoacanthomas
  • Sebaceous epitheliomas
  • Basal cell epitheliomas

questions.text: Which is the most common variant of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution: Invasive ductal carcinoma (not otherwise specified) is the most common variant of breast carcinoma. It is also known as infiltrating ductal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man came to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. He also mentioned that his pain was aggravated on fasting. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated gastrin levels. A diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES) was made. Which of the following is the most common site of gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastrinoma in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is the duodenum. 

The most common site of gastrinoma is the duodenum followed by the pancreas. Other less common sites include intraabdominal organs (such as the liver and stomach), ovaries, and rarely extra-abdominal sites such as the lungs and heart. 

Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor (NET) that is characterized by increased gastrin secretion. This stimulates the formation of gastric mucosa which leads to an increase in the secretion of gastric acid (Zollinger Ellison Syndrome). In a chronic setting, excess gastric acid secretion can result in the formation of peptic ulcers. Diarrhea is another common symptom of gastrinoma. Most gastrinomas are malignant. Gastrinomas can also occur as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia 1.

Laboratory investigations reveal gastrin levels of more than 1000 pg/ml along with pH less than or equal to 2.

Treatment options include conservative management with proton pump inhibitors initially. However, long term use may lead to Clostridium difficile infection. Cases that fail to respond to medical treatment are managed via surgical resection. In cases with lymph node metastasis or those with MEN1, Whipple's resection is done. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and passing of air bubbles in urine. He was diagnosed with diverticulitis 2 years before and was treated with antibiotics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of diverticulitis and pneumaturia point towards a diagnosis of colovesical fistula. The patients present with the symptoms of urinary tract infection caused by colonic flora, pneumaturia (air bubbles in urine), and fecaluria (foul-smelling and brownish material in the urine).

Complications of diverticular disease:

  • Bleeding
  • Perforation leading to a pericolic abscess or generalized peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction due to fibrosis
  • Fistula formation (colovesical, coloenteric, colovaginal)

Emphysematous cystitis can also present with pneumaturia. It is caused by urinary tract infection (UTI) with a gas-forming organism, especially in people with diabetes or patients with urinary tract outflow obstruction.

questions.text: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. 

NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.
