questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below)

Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with:

  • 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route
  • Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally
  • Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium

The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

questions.text: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by all except_____
questions.solution:
Critical limb ischemia is characterized by rest pain and/or ulceration and gangrene. Intermittent claudication progresses to rest pain in critical limb ischemia.

Rest pain occurs with the limb at rest and is felt in the foot; it is exacerbated by lying down or elevation of the foot. Characteristically, the pain is worse at night and it may be lessened by hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair. The pressure of clothes on the foot usually makes the pain worse.

Ulceration occurs with severe arterial insufficiency and may present as painful erosion between toes or as shallow, non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the feet, on the shins, and especially around the malleoli. The blackened mummified tissues of frank gangrene are unmistakable and superadded infection often makes the gangrene wet.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common indication for splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external (blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons).

The most common indication for:

  • Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc.
  • Emergency splenectomy - Trauma
  • Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is true about melanoma of the anal canal?

choices.text: Wide local excision is done for tumors with sphincter involvement
Staged by depth or thickness of melanoma lesion

questions.solution:
Anorectal melanoma is staged by the depth or thickness of the lesion.

Anal canal melanoma is more common in females. The tumor appears as small and polypoidal or large and ulcerating. Clinical features include:

  1. Anorectal bleeding, itching, pain, mass
  2. Tenesmus, and changes in bowel habits
  3. Mesorectal lymph node metastases
  4. Inguinal lymphadenopathy 
  5. Distant spread- to bones, lungs, and liver

Diagnosis is frequently made following hemorrhoidectomy or local excision of the perianal mass.

Treatment:

  • Tumors without anal sphincter involvement- wide local excision with negative margins
  • Large tumors invading sphincters- palliative APR 

Regardless of stage, 5-year survival rates for anorectal melanoma are very poor, averaging at about 6%. The median survival time following diagnosis is 12–18 months.

Note: Most common sites of melanoma are skin >eye > anorectal region

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?

choices.text: Injury to the lymphatic system can cause secondary lymphoedema
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
The sural nerve accompanies the short saphenous vein laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the great saphenous vein.

Surgery for the varicose veins extraction may trigger injury of the lymph vessels and may lead to secondary lymphedema.

Injury and inflammation to the venous system during varicose vein surgery can cause slowing and stasis of blood flow in the lower limb, making them prone to develop deep vein thrombosis postoperatively.

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: Chang staging is used for ?
questions.solution:
Chang staging is used for risk stratification of Medulloblastoma.

Staging for different cancers:

  • Chang staging – Medulloblastoma
  • Reiss and Ellsworth classification – Retinoblastoma
  • Noguchi classification – Adenocarcinoma lung
  • Nevine staging – Gall bladder Carcinoma
  • Shimda index – Neuroblastoma
  • Gleason score – Prostate carcinoma
  • Duke staging – Colorectal carcinoma
  • Robson staging – Renal cell carcinoma
  • Jackson staging – Penile carcinoma
  • Bloom Richardson grading – Breast carcinoma
  • Masaoaka staging  - Thymoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife presents with low-voltage electric burns injury. Such domestic low voltage electrical injury can cause all of the following except
questions.solution:
Electric injury -

The current enters at one point and then leaves the body at an exit point, usually to the earth or the neutral conductor of the electricity supply.  

It tends to take the shortest route between entry and best exit, irrespective of the varying conductivity of different internal tissues.

When a hand is brought into contact with a live conductor, and the body is earthed either through the feet or the opposite hand, the most common passage of current is across the heart.

It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart when compared with head to feet (up to 5.9 percent), left hand to feet (up to 5.1 percent), hand to hand (up to 4.4 percent) or foot to foot (up to 0.4 percent)

Direct current (d.c.) is less dangerous than alternating current (a.c.).

Most deaths from electricity are from cardiac arrhythmias, usually, ventricular fibrillation ending in cardiac arrest.

It is commonly said that tolerance can be gained to electric shock and that professional electricians often work on live 240 V conductors with impunity.

In the case of the person touching a 240-volt conductor while standing on a carpeted wooden floor upstairs, the poor earth will allow only a small current to flow and all that may be suffered is a painful muscular spasm.

The person touching the neutral and live wires with the same finger a few centimeters apart may suffer from a severe local burn but no danger to life.

Various skin lesions in electrical injury:

  • When the skin has been in firm contact with an electrical conductor, this may split the layers of the epidermis or the epidermal-dermal junction and produce a raised blister called Joule burns.
  • In high-voltage burns, such as those sustained from high-tension grid transmission cables, where the voltage is in the multi-kilovolt range, sparking may occur over many centimeters. This can cause multiple spark lesions giving rise to a ‘crocodile-skin’ effect.
  • The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci called as 'bone pearls' or 'wax drippings'.

  • When the contact with the electrocuting surface is not firm, the skin lesion that develops is called a spark lesion. When the contact is less firm, an air gap (albeit narrow) exists between skin and conductor the current jumps the gap as a spark. This causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area. On cooling, the keratin fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of a painless lump in her left breast which she noticed during a routine self-examination. On palpation, a hard lump with irregular margins and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes were found. Which among the following is the best modality to detect malignancy in her case?
questions.solution:
Tomosynthesis (3D mammography) performed along with conventional 2D mammography is the best investigation among the given options to detect breast carcinoma. 

Breast Tomosynthesis is typically performed in conjunction with conventional mammography. Hence, the radiation dose is doubled. However, the accuracy is improved and false positives are lesser. It can be used for dense breasts and those with high-risk factors.

Screen-film mammography is the conventional 2D mammography.

Digital mammography/full-field digital mammography uses digital technology instead of films. The diagnostic accuracy is similar to that of screen-film mammography. A minor advantage is the greater accuracy in predicting lesions in dense breasts.

Note: Overall, the best modality for detecting breast carcinoma is MRI.

questions.text: 70 kg male presents to the emergency following a stab injury to the abdomen. He is hypotensive, markedly tachycardic and appears confused. What percent of blood volume has he lost?
questions.solution:
Hypotension, marked tachycardia (i.e., pulse greater than 110–120 beats per minute/ bpm]), and confusion will be evident when more than 30% of the blood volume has been lost.

Classification of hemorrhage:

 

Parameter Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss (mL) <750 750 - 1500 1500 - 2000 >2000
Blood loss (%) <15 15 - 30 30 - 40 >40
Heart rate (bpm) <100 >100 >120 >140
Blood pressure Normal Orthostatic Hypotension Severe hypotension
Pulse pressure (mmHg) Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Capillary refill test Normal Positive Positive Positive
Respiratory rate 14 - 20 20- 30 30 - 40 >35
Urine output (mL/hr) ≥30 20 - 30 5 - 15 Negligible
CNS symptoms Normal Anxious Confused Obtunded
Fluid replacement Crystalloid Crystalloid Crystalloid + blood Crystalloid + blood

questions.text: What is the most common anomaly of the hepatic artery?

choices.text: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery

questions.solution:
The most common anomaly of the hepatic artery is replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery. 

Normally, the common hepatic artery gives off the right and left hepatic arteries. A middle hepatic artery branches off from the proximal left hepatic artery.

The replaced right hepatic artery directly supplies the right lobe of the liver.

Surgical significance: 

In individuals with replaced right hepatic artery, the diameter of the common hepatic artery is smaller. In liver transplant recipients, this can be a cause for the increased incidence of complications such as thrombosis.

Whereas, replaced right hepatic artery is a beneficial variant for donors undergoing donation of the right lobe of the liver. The replaced right hepatic artery provides a longer and larger graft thus reducing chances of thrombosis.

questions.text: Haggitt’s classification describes carcinoma invading neck of the polyp as level___________
questions.solution: Haggitt’s classification describes carcinoma invading neck of the polyp as level 2.

questions.text: Carneys triad includes all except
questions.solution:
Carneys triad is a rare occurrence of coexistence of 3 tumours namely:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is found to have a well-circumscribed mass in his liver and is suspected to have fibrolamellar HCC. Which of the following tumor markers will be elevated in his condition?
questions.solution:
Neurotensin is the tumor marker of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Neurotensin is a mitogen which induces cell proliferation in fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma. There is increased serum unsaturated vitamin B12 binding capacity seen in fibrolamellar HCC which can also aid in diagnosis.
